p.s: The given text is an extract of Act 1, Scene 7 of Macbeth, written by William Shakespeare.
The scene is about a conversation between Lady Macbeth and Macbeth where his wife persuades Macbeth to murder kingKing Duncan.

Right of the beginning of the dialogue, Lady Macbeth tries to convince her husband to kill Duncan after he went to his chamber, but Macbeth doesn't want to go on with this plan, because Duncan granted him the title Thane of Cawdor before and Macbeth wants to enjoy that honour.
Then his wife asks him what the reason for his changed opinion is and he answers that he doesn't want to get too arrogant.
Further on Lady Macbeth appeals to her husband that he should execute the plan he made himself and Macbeth responds that he doesn't know what to do if they would fail.
His wife wants him to get his courage up and tells him about the exact plan about how she would help Macbeth killing kingKing Duncan.
